Innovation is the process of bringing scientific discoveries to market. Nowadays with the rise of Biotech the distinction between science and engineering has blurred, which may confuse the issues. There are shortages of engineers in many fields and there have been for a long time in some areas. There is also a shortage of doctors which has contributed to rising health care costs — fewer people consider medicine a desirable profession due to increasing hassles of the job. The engineering situation is similar in that many young people feel engineers are unhappy despite the good money. In the area of software engineering the working environment has improved but here the low hanging fruit metaphor is a big factor — innovations in computer science are not moving well, perhaps due to business factors. Since the finance industry is both exciting and overpaying it is very attractive to the brightest young people. If this industry were better regulated perhaps some of the revenue could be redirected to areas which are currently in need of encouragement. Oftentimes the Chinese take the lead in industries because their government is supporting them better than ours is — and more generally innovation in engineering and computer software does help reduce costs to industry, so the situation is not just about lower wages or higher motivation for higher wages. Innovators *are* heroes in America especially those who create wealth and new popular experiences.

William M. @38 -

Missing from your analysis is the impact all these "savings" have on people's health. It's very easy to cut costs if you take the health of the patient out of the occasion. Think about how much we could save in social security and Medicare if life expectancy dropped by a few years.

It's all well and good for employers like Safeway to see savings by shifting costs onto their employees, but how has it been for the employees? Particlularly employees who have chronic conditions? Have you considered the possibility that being responsible for one's health might mean being in increased contact with one's physician, not less? Asthma, Juvenile diabetes, Crone's disease, MS, high blood pressure can all be expensive illneses.

I would like to suggest that the idea that healthy people getting too much healthcare and driving up costs is a myth. The fact is, that hospitals and doctors make profits off of people getting routine care, and to some extent, doesn't that offset the costs of treating more expensive patients? With the uninsured getting emergency room care, if hospitals end up shifting costs onto their paying patients, won't that drive up the cost for those patients?

I agree that health insurance is not designed to deal with the unexpected, rare, and catastrophic event. The fact is that "catastrophic illness" is not that rare at all, which is why health insurance is expensive. Giving healthy people money not to see the doctor via health savings accounts does nothing to offset the costs of people with serious medical expenses.

If having more skin in the game makes people healthier, why is it that in countries with universal healthcare, and not nearly as much skin in the game as our 30+ million uninsured, are people so much healthier? Could it be that having access to a doctor actually makes them healthier? By your logic they would all be neglecting their health, because they aren't worried about healthcare costs. One would also think that the unhealthiest people in our country would be the ones with the best insurance policies. But I believe, and you can correct me if I'm wrong, that it is poorer people in this country, with less health insurance who are actually in worse shape.

Saying that requiring people to pay more out of pocket strikes me as a convenient excuse to avoid having to fund healthcare adequately. Kind of like when people like Andrew Carnegie rationalized not giving their employees weekends off, by claiming they would just spend the time getting drunk.

Refusing to acknowledge that you treat some people shabbily and then blaming those people for self destructive behaviors appears to be the modus operandi of conservatives. In Massachusetts, raising cigarette taxes lowered the percentage of smokers in all income groups except the lowest. With the new Massachusetts healthcare plan, when these smokers were able to get into smoking cessation programs, more of them quit.

Of course, if you point out cases where gov't works, then people will bash it for being a "nanny state". Locking up mentally ill people for crimes is acceptable. Giving people access to medical care and support services isn't.

I agree with Eric in Ontario. I would like our US administration to remember our own American Revolution. I also want them to ask themselves if they aren't going along with the same arguments that were used to keep African-Americans from obtaining their legitimate rights following the Emancipation Proclamation: "Oh, they aren't ready for democracy, it's going to take time" and so on. The protesters in Tahrir Square are presenting an Egyptian version of our Civil Rights movement. And this appeal to "stability" is laughable, in my view; I can't imagine a more unstable situation than what's going on right now. Pay attention to who is wanting the stability. I just hope that our administration realizes that we could prove to be our own worst enemy, if we insist on stability instead of being true to our principles.

As Henry Kissinger said the other day, the US should proclaim its allegiance with the Egyptian people.  But that does not mean an abrupt exit for Mr. Mubarak.  Under Egypt's constitution the President should stay until his term expires in September.  This means an orderly transition to another government.  Mr. Mubarak has said he will not seek another term.  The tide has turned toward a new future for the Egyptian people.  They would benefit from the formation of a stable government to replace Mr. Mubarak when he leaves.  By waiting just a few months to allow for careful deliberations Egypt can confidently embrace the future with more optimism.

Programs that are flawed at their foundation will not benefit from this approach. The best way to make government "work better" is to simply reduce it. All major government spending is characterized by waste, fraud, and corruption, as illustrated by the statistics in this article. As government expands, the economy suffers. There is no such thing as "market discipline" for politically-conceived programs.

Obviously government programs with specific objects (e.g., making sure people don't go malnourished) should be evaluated for success and modified or abandoned if they don't measure up. I consider myself a progressive, which means I believe in the public good, not the pursuit of greed, and I believe government has a vital role in creating the public good. That also means I am the nastiest critic and bean counter when it comes to effectively spending tax dollars to accomplish these purposes. I have always advocated limiting what could be purchased with food stamps so as to maximize nutrition for expenditure, and I blame both the food industry and advocates for the right of the poor to eat as badly as the rich for waste (WIC is much better). I tear our local "economic development" projects to shreds, because they don't have a means for assessing if the anything is accomplished, and I accuse both state and local governments of having an economic development bureaucracy with a vested interest in their own jobs that resists program evaluation (and a lot of special interests who benefit—Brownfields have made welfare a way of life for developers).

I seriously doubt a few test programs that use market-like incentives will have an impact. The real solution is political—proponents of government spending are the ones who should be leading a war on waste and demanding bang for buck. Remember it is budget cutting Republican hypocrites who don't want evidenced-based medicine and don't want doctors and patients to talk about end of life, talks that typically lead patients to choose dying with dignity over pointless, expensive, interventions and life-support.

Government programs "don't work" because they are starved for public funds!  Indeed, basic social services are being slashed as we speak all in the name of "market principles."  Sorry, but undemocratic, profit-driven institutions are broken, and, right now, they are destroying society and the environment at a record pace.  Investments driven by short-run gain are throwing people out of work in the U.S. (who then need "government programs"), and destroying the biosphere by "efficiently" exploiting every last natural resource.  We don't need more capitalism, we need a new paradigm!

Interesting article, but like a lot of policy it is too long-winded and thereby ultimately diluted in effectiveness.
In today's climate, a simple reality check is needed for government programs:
Budgets are tight, but work still has to get done. Therefore, U.S. Military get everything you need to get done this year that you got done last year, but do it with 5% less money.

So some people may have to work harder, work smarter and some people that are ineffective may have to be laid off. Welcome to the real world!

Silly, really, it's a silly idea. If nobody knows why something does not work, the last thing to do is to spend huge amounts of money on schemes by people who promise it will cost you nothing to give them a shot at it. It's no different than gambling. Public money will be spent to support these efforts and if they cannot perform, all they need to do is declare bankruptcy to avoid losing any money, at all.

Nobody knows why recidivism is so high for paroled and released offenders, nor why pre-school programs work great until after the 3rd grade, nor why people have so much trouble working themselves out of impoverished conditions with the help of strong social welfare programs.

First we need to understand the processes that are ending in these results. Then it will be possible to frame conditions for accountability and to write contracts that will be able to be enforced.

saying poverty is the same as in 1981, despite anti-poverty programs, tells us nothing.  Because there's a very real possibility that poverty would have increased dramatically without those programs.  You can't just conduct broad tests of does X work or not, you have to have control groups to get reasonable data.
